H0.text: The cochlea is the structure in the inner ear that is lined by hair cells which convert vibrations into electrical signals.

H1.text: Ear canal is the structure in the inner ear that is lined by hair cells which convert vibrations into electrical signals.

H2.text: Hammer is the structure in the inner ear that hair cells line to convert vibrations into electrical signals.

H3.text: Ear lobe is the part of the inner ear lined by hair cells that convert vibrations into electrical signals.

A4.text: The hair cells in the organ of Corti are tuned to certain sound frequencies by way of their location in the cochlea, due to the degree of stiffness in the basilar membrane.

A5.text: The cochlea receives sound in the form of vibrations, which cause the stereocilia to move.
